name: General Knowledge 102 Quiz | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: What is the most popular team sport in Australia in terms of aggregate attendance figures?
questions.explanation:
Aussie Rules.

	A version of Irish Gaelic football, first played to keep cricketers fit during the winter.

questions.text: Maxi Jazz is a member of which famous UK band?
questions.explanation:
Faithless.

	Maxi Jazz known as 'The Grand Oral Disseminator', along with Jamie Catto, Sister Bliss and Rollo make up this great UK dance group.

questions.text: Who is the author of the book titled 'The Long Walk'?
questions.explanation:
all of these.

	Written in 1979 under the pseudonym of Richard Bachman, one of my all time favourite King books. There is also a book written under the same title by Slavomir Rawicz so another trivia player pointed out to me.

questions.text: Which of these is not a type of roux?
questions.explanation:
Black roux.

	A combination of fat and flour, cooked to one of three stages, mainly used as a base of sauces and soups.

questions.text: Where would you find an Ocelot?
questions.explanation:
Central and South America.

	An ocelot is a small leopard like mammal found in Central and South America.

questions.text: What is the first language of the modern Olympics?
questions.explanation: French.

questions.text: Who invented the telephone?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell.

questions.text: Which other planet in our solar system is said to be Earth's sister planet?
questions.explanation:
Venus.

	Said because it is almost identical in size and density.

questions.text: What is the world's largest fish?
questions.explanation: Whale Shark.

questions.text: In Australia what are third degree burns now known as?
questions.explanation:
Full thickness.

	Full thickness = third degree, Partial thickness = second degree, Superficial =first degree. I know this because I received all three types almost ten years ago.

questions.text: The moon affects what on Earth?
questions.explanation: Tides.

questions.text: If I was travelling at Mach 1 what speed would I be going?
questions.explanation:
Speed of sound.

	Mach speed was named after Ernst Mach an Austrian physicist, 1836-1916.  It is not possible for anything man-made to reach the speed of light.

questions.text: Who is credited with the first ever design of a helicopter?
questions.explanation: Leonardo Da Vinci.

questions.text: In which year did Captain Cook land on Australia?
Brisbane is the capital city of which Australian state?
questions.explanation:
Queensland.

	Brisbane, {Queensland;} Adelaide, {South Australia;} Hobart, {Tasmania;} Canberra, (the Nation's capital), Australian Capital Territory.

questions.text: What is Espagnole?
questions.explanation: Brown sauce.

questions.text: Who won five consecutive motorcycle world championships (500cc) during the 1990s?
questions.explanation:
Michael Doohan.

	After suffering horrific leg injuries while leading the world championship in 1992, Mick came back to win the next five years, before another sreious crash forced him to retire.

questions.text: New Zealand has a larger population than Papua New Guinea.
questions.explanation: False.

questions.text: In what year was the great Fire of London?
questions.explanation:
1666.

	Although it destroyed half of the city of London, only six people were injured.  The previous year the Great Plague rampaged through the city, killing thousands.  The fire went a long way to clearing out the rats, who carried the fleas which spread the disease.

questions.text: The Italian Renaissance began in which century?
questions.explanation: 14th.

questions.text: What is the sixth largest country in area in the world?
questions.explanation:
Australia.

	Russian Federation 6,592,735 sq miles, Canada 3,851,809 sq miles, China 3,705,386 sq miles, USA 3,615,122 sq miles, Brazil 3,286,500 sq miles, Australia 2,967,893 sq miles.

questions.text: Krypton is an element on the periodic table.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Element number 36 a colourless, inert gas found in the atmosphere, it is used in electic light globes.

questions.text: The Super Whopper, the world's largest water slide can be found where?
questions.explanation:
Kobe, Japan.

	Its 50 different tubes allow 12,000 people to pass through every hour.

questions.text: Where was Coca-cola produced originally?
questions.explanation:
Atlanta.

	Atlanta, Georgia by a pharmacist Dr John S Pemberton, in 1896 I believe.

questions.text: The Tri-Nations series is played between which three nations?
questions.correct: Australia, South Africa and New Zealand
options: New Zealand, South Africa and Great Britain
Great Britain, South Africa and Canada
questions.explanation:
Australia, South Africa and New Zealand.

	A rugby union series that determines the Tri-nations Champion, as well as the Bledisloe Cup between Australia and New Zealand.
